qas.question: What do household animals prey upon?
Name an exemplar of an predator that uses digestion to kill and gain nutrients from it's prey.
To be classified as a predator, what action must be performed?

answers.text: harm their prey in some way

qas.question: What requirement must a true predator fulfill?

answers.text: kills and eats another living thing

qas.question: What is different about a true predator?

answers.text: Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, this form kills them

qas.question: All types of predators do what?

answers.text: harm their prey in some way
sit and wait for prey to approach within striking distance

qas.question: What do box jellyfish use to hunt their pray?
What is one thing prey can do if they know a predator is approaching?
What do prey sometimes consume as food?
What do rabbits like to do with their food when foraging?
What do large insects do at night after the sun goes down?
What have cats sometimes been seen doing in the yard of their home?

context: A true predator can commonly be known as one that <a3_0>kills and eats <b9_0>another living thing<b9_0/><a3_0/>. <a4_0>Whereas other types of predator all <a2_0><a5_0>harm their prey in some way<a5_0/><a2_0/>, this form kills them<a4_0/>. Predators may <b11_0>hunt actively<b11_0/> for prey in pursuit predation, or <a6_0><b8_0>sit and wait<b8_0/> for prey to approach within striking distance<a6_0/>, as in ambush predators. Some predators kill large prey and dismember or <b10_0>chew it<b10_0/> prior to eating it, such as a jaguar or a human; others may eat their (usually much smaller) prey whole, as does a bottlenose dolphin swallowing a fish, or a snake, duck or stork swallowing a frog. Some animals that kill both <a0_0>large and small prey<a0_0/> for their size (domestic cats and dogs are prime examples) may do either depending upon the circumstances; either would devour a large insect whole but dismember a rabbit. Some predation entails <a7_0>venom<a7_0/> that subdues a prey creature before the predator ingests the prey by killing, which the box jellyfish does, or disabling it, found in the behavior of the cone shell. In some cases, the venom, as in rattlesnakes and some spiders, contributes to the digestion of the prey item even before the predator begins eating. In other cases, the prey organism may die in the mouth or digestive system of the predator. <a1_0>Baleen whales<a1_0/>, for example, eat millions of microscopic plankton at once, the prey being broken down well after entering the whale. Seed predation and egg predation are other forms of true predation, as seeds and eggs represent potential organisms. Predators of this classification need not eat prey entirely. For example, some predators cannot digest bones, while others can. Some may eat only part of an organism, as in <b12_0>grazing<b12_0/> (see below), but still consistently cause its direct death.
